summary_points.title: Weekly Market Rebound
summary_points.summary: After a brief correction, Indian benchmark indices staged a strong comeback last week, with the BSE Sensex rising 0.88% and both Sensex and Nifty closing the week with gains of around 1%. Midcap and smallcap segments outperformed as optimism around potential GST reforms and sustained domestic institutional investor buying helped markets recover from their recent corrective phase.

summary_points.title: Technical Levels to Watch
summary_points.summary: Technically, the critical support for the Sensex lies at the 50-day SMA near 81,900, with a break below likely to test the 20-day SMA in the 81,100–81,000 zone and potentially dragging levels down to 80,700–80,400. On the upside, immediate resistance is in the 82,000–82,200 zone, with a decisive breakout above 82,500 opening the path toward 83,300. An indecisive ‘inside body’ daily candle further underscores choppy trading conditions.

summary_points.title: Jackson Hole-Induced Pullback
summary_points.summary: Markets snapped a six-day winning streak as panic selling ahead of Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s Jackson Hole speech drove the Nifty 50 down by 213 points to 24,870, the Sensex by 693 points to 81,306, and the Bank Nifty by 606 points to 55,149. Auto heavyweights—M&M, Maruti, and BEL—emerged as top gainers, while Grasim, Asian Paints, and Adani Enterprises led the losses, reflecting a risk-off sentiment.

summary_points.title: Trading Caution Ahead of US Tariffs
summary_points.summary: Ahead of the US tariffs on Indian goods, markets are poised for a weak start on August 26, mirroring global equity weakness and an 85-point discount in Gift Nifty near 24,905. Although Monday saw the Sensex gain 329 points, the Nifty slipped below 24,900, and an inside candle formation points to uncertainty in the immediate session as investors assess the trade and geopolitical risks.

summary_points.title: MarketSmith’s Stock Picks Amid Reversal
summary_points.summary: MarketSmith India recommends Tega Industries and Aadhar Housing Finance after Friday’s sharp reversal ended a six-day rally, with the Nifty closing 0.85% lower at 24,870. Selling pressure was pronounced in banking and metals, yet the week ended on a positive note thanks to GST reform hopes and DII support. The selected stocks align with prevailing technical patterns and remain poised for a potential rebound.

top_performing_sectors.explanation: Nifty FMCG rose about 0.9% on expectations of increased consumption amid proposed GST reforms.
Auto stocks such as Eicher Motors and Maruti Suzuki led gains, buoyed by resilient consumer demand and strong quarterly showings.

underperforming_sectors.explanation: Nifty Realty plunged nearly 2% as profit‐booking hit property developers amid weak market sentiment.
Metal stocks fell almost 2% on renewed concerns over global demand and disappointing earnings outlooks.
Nifty Bank and Financial Services dropped around 1.3% due to heavy selling in HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank and other large private lenders.

gainers.reason: Shares jumped 2.68% to top the Nifty gainers list, though no specific catalyst was mentioned.
Advanced 2.32% as the FMCG sector rallied on expectations of increased consumption amid proposed GST reforms.
Rose around 1.85% as auto heavyweights gained on optimism over potential US Fed rate cuts boosting demand.

losers.reason: Tumbled 4.03% as the broader market sell-off particularly hit financial stocks.
Dropped 3.35% after reports that the US President levied additional tariffs on Indian exports.
Fell 2.87% amid sector-wide selling pressure in metals.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s flat trading reflects a tug-of-war between healthy domestic liquidity—buoyed by falling interest rates and potential tax reforms—and a moderation in corporate earnings growth that has tempered investor enthusiasm. Foreign institutional investors have also trimmed positions, largely on profit‐booking and portfolio rebalancing amid tariff uncertainty and global supply-chain concerns. While global cues and geopolitical stability remain watchpoints, a revival in consumer spending and a pickup in private sector investment are seen as the most likely catalysts for a sustainable up-move, with long-term gains ultimately hinging on steady macro fundamentals, earnings revival and attractive relative valuations.
